Article Title: WWW inventor says AI may become more powerful than its creator
Article Text:
‚ÄòMust be universal‚Äô, P 5

'Biggest AI Summit': Ashwini Vaishnaw Says India AI Impact Summit Getting 'Phenomenal Response'

Artificial intelligence has an exciting role to play in fields like drug discovery, scientific progress and disease treatment. But given the pace at which it is evolving, there is a real prospect of AI becoming more powerful than its creator, warns Tim Berners-Lee, British computer scientist and inventor of the World Wide Web.Humanity will have to figure out to how deal with super intelligence, says Berners-Lee, striking a note of caution at a time when companies and govts seem to be in a race to develop AI without really thinking through the consequences.Speaking to Jaya Bhattacharji Rose, Berners-Lee described ChatGPT as a "phase change", which surprised him with its conversational power. He emphasised that the critical question is who an AI works for.He argued for assistants that serve the user's best interests - analogous to a doctor's duty - rather than corporate incentives. He connected this to his Solid project and his company's work on user-controlled data "pods", aiming to restore agency by letting individuals control and selectively share their personal data, including in child-safe configurations with parental oversight.Berners-Lee also contrasted the early web's democratic spirit with today's platform-dominated experience. In the beginning, individuals could publish their own websites and participate on equal footing with major institutions.
Article Summary: Tim Berners-Lee, inventor of the World Wide Web, spoke at India AI Impact Summit. He warned that AI could become more powerful than its creator. He argued for assistants that serve the user's best interests, rather than corporate incentives. He compared the early web's democratic spirit with today's platform- dominated experience.

Article Title: Government confident it did better in battle of wits with opposition
Article Text:
Opposition targets LS Speaker with no-confidence motion ‚Äî rules, process & numbers ‚Äì Explained

NEW DELHI: Any hope of normalcy returning to LS was apparently dashed when opposition stepped up their offensive and submitted a notice for the removal of the Speaker. In a twist, it turned out to be the end of a week-long impasse, laying bare faultlines within the opposition as pragmatic voices wanting to be heard on key issues in the House prevailed over those favouring uncompromising rigidity and confrontation.LS functioned normally even though the govt did not agree to the conditions set by Congress: allowing LoP Rahul Gandhi to speak, rectification of the Speaker‚Äôs ‚Äúbaseless‚Äù claim that he had to request PM not to speak during the debate on motion of thanks to the President for her address in view of plans of Congress‚Äô MPs to do something unprecedented, and a probe into why BJP MP Nishikant Dubey‚Äôs mic was not switched off when he attacked Nehru-Gandhi family.The prevailing view within govt was that it had come out better in the battle of wits by not making any concession to the key Congress demand of allowing Rahul to speak first and revoking the suspension of eight MPs to defuse the crisis that had stalled proceedings.What helped the govt defuse the impasse was the keenness among some key regional BJP rivals for LS to function and allow discussion on regional concerns. Bengal and Tamil Nadu, where TMC and DMK are in office, are headed to polls, while political temperature is rising in UP, where Samajwadi Party is the main opposition party, with elections only a year away.While TMC made its differences clear by not signing the notice, MPs from different non-Congress oppn parties suggested many of them did not want the first half of the session to be consumed by the deadlock.Across the aisle, BJP‚Äôs allies stood firm with the govt, backing the Speaker and criticising the opposition for targeting a constitutional office.Taking high moral ground, Birla decided not to attend till the notice is disposed of, signalling the matter may be taken up later in the session.
Article Summary: LS functioned normally even though the govt did not agree to the conditions set by Congress. The prevailing view within govt was that it had come out better in the battle of wits by not making any concession to the key Congress demand of allowing Rahul to speak first.

The night of Super Bowl LX was more than just football and a show. A competing halftime show away from the main broadcast stirred up feelings, controversy, and political symbolism. Turning Point USA pushed its All American Halftime Show as a patriotic alternative, drawing attention not only for its message but for the personal grief woven into the production.In the hours after the show aired, Erika Kirk broke her silence. Her words reframed the night as something deeper than a ratings fight or culture war moment. For supporters, it became a tribute. For critics, it raised fresh questions about politics, platform power, and how grief is carried into public space.The alternative show, organized by Turning Point USA, aired opposite Bad Bunny ‚Äôs NFL halftime performance during the championship game between the New England Patriots and the Seattle Seahawks. Headlined by Kid Rock, the event leaned heavily into honoring the late Charlie Kirk, who was killed in September.A montage played during the broadcast featured Kirk‚Äôs own words, including: ‚ÄúI want to honor God in all that I do. I want to be a great husband, a great father.I want to serve this country,‚Äù followed by: ‚ÄúI want to try to continue to lead this movement and to speak truth and to never lie, to stop thinking about yourself all of the time, and instead think about what you should do to help other people and defend this country above yourself.She further added, ‚ÄúI am so inspired by this army of freedom fighters. We‚Äôre going to be around for the next 100, 200 years because we know in the end our ideas will win.‚ÄùErika Kirk did not attend the event, but she later praised it publicly, calling the show ‚Äúso incredible‚Äù and adding, ‚ÄúCharlie would‚Äôve absolutely loved it. Thank you to the millions that tuned in.‚ÄùShe closed her message with a personal note that resonated across social media: ‚ÄúUltimately, this is what it‚Äôs all about, making Heaven crowded.‚Ä¶I love you Charlie baby, this is all for you.‚ÄùDespite being blocked from streaming on X, the broadcast claimed millions of viewers across platforms. Whether those numbers hold or not, the emotional weight of the tribute ensured the night would be remembered for more than just music or politics.

There are voices in the cricket world which insist that Tariq chucks that delivery and that he shouldn‚Äôt be allowed to play.But the mystery spinner has found an ally from an unusual quarter in the form of the master of the craft of off-spin, R Ashwin, who posted his support on X.Eminent batting coach and former India player WV Raman, too, believes Tariq isn‚Äôt chucking, but India shouldn‚Äôt find it difficult to play him. ‚ÄúWith a round-arm ac-tion it is very difficult to chuck ‚Ä¶ It is the quirkiness of Tariq‚Äôs ac-tion that is creating the problem. Batters are used to a rhythm where everything keeps happening in one go. When suddenly there is a pause, you start thinking about what‚Äôs go-ing on,‚Äù Raman told TOI.‚ÄúBut Indian batters are good enough to deal with this. Kedar Jadhav and Riyan Parag bowl like that from time to time, so it‚Äôs not that they are not used to it,‚Äù he said. Over the next few days, the chat-ter will continue. The Indian play-ers are superb players of spin bowl-ing, somebody like Shivam Dube being a designated spin-hitter. Pakistan will have a few more spin-ners in their XI in the form of Mo-hammed Nawaz, Abrar Ahmed and Shadab Khan and India will need all their skill to deal with the threat, led by Tariq.

Investigators said the gang carried out multiple burglaries between Feb 1 and 5, striking residential properties and attempting to break into jewellery showrooms.A senior police officer said the first incident was reported on the night of Feb 1, when a group broke into a bungalow in Raj Nagar while the owners were away. Officers said the group broke the lock of one showroom around 3am and was trying to cut chain locks on the rear door of an adjacent store when neighbours noticed the activity and alerted police. The suspects fled before stealing anything, but a robbery case was registered. Later the same night, police got information about a burglary at a locked flat in SPS Apartment Society in Sahibabad.The suspects allegedly stole gold, silver and cash before escaping in a white Ertiga.ADCP Piyush Kumar Singh said CCTV footage from multiple locations, along with eyewitness accounts describing seven men, helped investigators establish that the same gang was behind the series of thefts.On Tuesday, a crime branch team arrested four suspects near an underpass close to Sahibabad railway station. They were identified as Roshan Yadav (26), Nimish Aggarwal (34), Raghu Kumar (42), and Aman Saxena (28). During questioning, Aggarwal allegedly told police that he had previously worked as a sales manager at one of the jewellery stores targeted in the break-in, but was later dismissed. He then took up a job at a jewellery showroom in Delhi, from where he allegedly stole ornaments and was jailed. While serving his sentence in Tihar, he came into contact with Raghu Kumar and other associates, police officials said. After he was recently released on bail, he allegedly failed to find work. He regrouped with his fellow inmates and planned the burglaries, police added. Some gold jewellery has been recovered from the accused, and efforts are under way to trace and arrest other gang members.

Article Title: 'Great adventure': French duo reach Shanghai after 518-day walk across 16 countries
Article Text:

Two French adventurers have completed an epic journey on foot from France to Shanghai, arriving on Saturday after nearly a year and a half and crossing 16 countries almost entirely on foot.Loic Voisot and Benjamin Humblot celebrated their arrival on the Bund promenade, with Shanghai‚Äôs skyline in the background.The pair began their journey from Annecy in September 2024."We were thinking about this moment almost every day for more than a year now, so it's a really strong feeling," Humblot was quoted as saying by AFP after reaching the destination."I think first and foremost we're proud, especially of having dared to do this... Then we had this slightly crazy idea of going on foot," Humblot said.Apart from a short stretch in Russia completed by bus for safety reasons, they walked for 518 days, covering around 12,850 kilometres (7,980 miles) before reaching Shanghai."We're both conscious of climate change, and the responsibility humans bear for it... there are some actions we can take individually," Voisot, a climate consultant said, as cited by AFP.Around 50 people gathered at the starting point for the final 10-kilometre stretch, including local residents who had followed their journey on social media. Their following grew along the route, with media, French residents in Shanghai and others joining them along the way.The French duo said they faced significant challenges during the journey, including harsh winters and a desert crossing in Uzbekistan. ‚ÄúThere were very hard winters, we had to cross the desert in Uzbekistan,‚Äù Voisot said, adding that he was proud of ‚Äúhaving had the willpower to always keep going.‚ÄùHumblot said they generally ate well during the trip but noted that they both missed French cheese.Asked what he would do first after completing the journey, Voisot replied that he would, ‚Äúsleep a lot!‚Äù
Article Summary: Loic Voisot and Benjamin Humblot began their journey from Annecy in September 2024. The pair walked for 518 days, covering around 12,850 kilometres (7,980 miles) They decided to travel to China without flying, citing environmental concerns.

Article Title: Indian family loses AED 50,000 worth gold in trash: Heartwarming recovery by Dubai police in 3 days wins the Internet

An unusual yet uplifting incident out of Dubai has captured global attention this February 2026 as an Indian family lost gold worth AED 50,000 (about ‚Çπ12‚Äì13 lakh) by mistake, when it was tossed out with household garbage, only for it to be tracked down and returned to them within just three days. The story has resonated far beyond the Gulf, trending across social media as an extraordinary example of civic efficiency, honesty and urban systems that deliver unexpectedly positive outcomes.According to multiple reports, the incident began when Kamini Kannan, an Indian who had previously lived in Dubai for 23 years, was visiting the city for a family wedding. By the next morning, the family realised the valuables were missing and a moment of panic seized them, given the gold‚Äôs high value and sentimental importance.Despite initial fears that the gold was irretrievably lost, the unexpected turnaround began when a waste-collection worker found the pouch while sorting rubbish.Instead of keeping it, he handed it over to authorities, a small act that set in motion a rapid recovery effort.Dubai Police, known for their efficient record systems and community cooperation, quickly traced the gold back to the family through building waste collection data and followed up with a call to Abhimanyu within three days. When the son arrived at the building reception, officers confirmed that the missing items had been found and would be returned.This seamless recovery, from garbage to reunion with owners, highlights both the city‚Äôs sophisticated waste tracking and police follow-up systems as well as the integrity shown by the worker who could easily have chosen to keep the find. Beyond the obvious human drama of years of savings nearly gone in minutes, the incident has drawn attention as a feel-good tale about civic trust and effective public service.Many social media users observed that such recoveries are not only about modern administrative systems but also reflect community values and ethical responsibility in everyday life. The story quickly went viral, spawning widespread coverage that underscored Dubai‚Äôs reputation for order and safety.Dubai‚Äôs efficient police and administrative coordination, often praised in other contexts for handling complex cases, proved capable of solving even this highly unlikely scenario in record time.This episode offers lessons in urban planning, data use and civic cooperation. Rather than dismissing an ‚Äúimpossible‚Äù loss, Dubai Police followed procedural leads and contacted the family directly, demonstrating responsiveness even in unusual cases.The garbage worker‚Äôs decision to hand in valuable gold illustrates the role of individual ethics in amplifying the effectiveness of city systems. As Dubai continues to position itself as a global hub for safety, innovation and quality of life, stories like this, blending modern administrative tools with human values, help shape international perceptions of the city‚Äôs societal fabric.For the Kannan family, the experience was both a shock and a blessing. Online audiences around the world reacted with admiration for the worker who turned the find in and the police who made the connection, noting that in many places such a scenario ends in permanent loss or legal disputes.The incident has become something of a viral emblem of hope and proof that sometimes small acts of honesty and robust governance infrastructure can combine to achieve remarkable results. What started as a small household mistake nearly turning into a major financial loss instead became a widely-shared story of recovery, system efficiency and community integrity.The Indian family‚Äôs gold, almost forever gone, was traced and returned in just three days thanks to an upright waste worker and proactive policing in Dubai, illustrating how modern cities can harness technology and human values to protect residents even in the most unexpected circumstances.
Article Summary: An Indian family lost gold worth AED 50,000 when it was tossed out with household garbage. Article Title: ‚ÄòI was really scared‚Äô: 13-year-old swims miles to save mom and siblings swept out to Sea
Article Text: A 13-year-old Australian boy who swam for hours to raise the alarm after his family was swept kilometres out to sea has downplayed his extraordinary act of courage.‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt think I was a hero ‚Äì I just did what I did‚Äù the boy told the BBC. Austin Appelbee was kayaking and paddleboarding with his mother Joanne, 47, brother Beau, 12, and sister Grace, 8, off Quindalup beach in Geographe Bay, Western Australia, on January 30 when strong winds pushed them far from shore. What began as a relaxed family outing quickly turned into a terrifying 10-hour ordeal.‚ÄúThe wind picked up and it went from there,‚Äù Joanne told the BBC. ‚ÄúWe lost oars, and we drifted out further‚Ä¶ It kind of all went wrong very, very quickly.‚ÄùRealising they were being carried farther out to sea and unable to paddle back, Joanne made what she later described as one of the hardest decisions of her life, sending her eldest son back to shore for help. ‚ÄúEarly on, we sent this young man back in to try and get help because it didn‚Äôt look like we were that far from the shoreline,‚Äù she said.Austin set off in the family‚Äôs kayak, unaware it had been badly damaged and was already taking on water.‚ÄúIt started flipping, and then I lost an oar and I knew I was in trouble,‚Äù he told the BBC.After struggling to keep the kayak afloat, he eventually abandoned it and began swimming.Battling fading light, rising waves and exhaustion, Austin swam roughly 4km (about two nautical miles), at one point discarding his lifejacket because it was hindering his movement.‚ÄúIt was getting dangerous now ‚Äì I had been out for a couple of hours,‚Äù he recalled. He later admitted he was ‚Äúreally scared‚Äù but said thinking about his family, friends and even singing Christian songs in his head kept him going.When he finally reached land around 6 pm local time, a disoriented Austin made his way along the beach to find a phone and dial Australia‚Äôs emergency number, triple-zero.In the call, later released by Western Australia Police with his mother‚Äôs permission, he told the dispatcher: ‚ÄúWe got swept out to sea, and we got lost out there‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm really scared.‚ÄùHe added: ‚ÄúI haven‚Äôt seen them since. I think they‚Äôre kilometres out in sea, I think we need helicopters to go find them.‚Äù Fearing hypothermia and dizziness, he also requested an ambulance.Shortly after making the call, Austin collapsed and was taken to hospital. He still did not know if his family had survived.Meanwhile, Joanne and the two younger children had drifted nearly 14km (8.5 miles) offshore, clinging to two paddleboards. ‚ÄúI had assumed Austin hadn‚Äôt made it,‚Äù Joanne told the BBC. ‚ÄúAs the day progressed, no vessels and nothing coming to save us.‚ÄùA large multi-agency search was launched, and by 8:30 pm ‚Äî nearly 10 hours after the family first entered the water ‚Äî rescuers located Joanne, Beau and Grace. All three were wearing life jackets and were later treated at a local hospital before being released without serious injuries.Austin said the moment he learned they had been found was unforgettable. ‚ÄúIt was a moment I will never forget,‚Äù he told the BBC, describing how doctors and police officers around him erupted in joy.Western Australia Police praised the teenager‚Äôs composure during the emergency call. Acting Sergeant Andrew McDonnell, who coordinated the rescue effort, said in a statement:‚ÄúWhat Austin did was nothing short of extraordinary. His bravery and courage in those conditions were remarkable, and his actions were pivotal in bringing about a successful outcome.‚ÄùWhile releasing emergency calls is not standard practice, police said they shared the recording with permission from Austin‚Äôs mother to educate the public about responding calmly in life-threatening situations.Despite being hailed as ‚Äúsuperhuman‚Äù by rescuers, Austin insists he was simply doing what needed to be done ‚Äî a sentiment that has only amplified admiration for the courageous teen across Australia.
Article Summary: Austin Appelbee was kayaking and paddleboarding with his mother Joanne, 47, brother Beau, 12, and sister Grace, 8, off Quindalup beach in Geographe Bay, Western Australia, on January 30. Strong winds pushed them far from shore and Joanne sent her eldest son back to shore for help. Austin swam roughly 4km (about two nautical miles) to find a phone and dial Australia‚Äôs emergency number, triple-zero.

Article Title: Ghost trees rising from ice: The 100-year-old earthquake that created Kazakhstan‚Äôs eerie underwater forest
Article Text:
Source: IFLScience

How Kaindy Lake became home to a frozen forest under water



Nature preserved in ice at Kaindy Lake







The story of nature tucked away in Kazakhstan‚Äôs Tian Shan Mountains, Kaindy Lake, seems like something out of a dream. Tree trunks poke eerily out of the water, ghostly and silent. It‚Äôs strange. Almost unreal. Locals and travellers alike are drawn to it, though, curious to see a forest frozen in time. Over a century ago, an earthquake changed the landscape, creating the lake and preserving the trees beneath its cold, clear surface. Experts say the water never warms above six degrees, which keeps the spruce trees surprisingly intact. It seems like nature hit pause, leaving something both haunting and beautiful.As reported by IFLScience , the story goes back to 1911, when a massive earthquake of magnitude 8 reportedly shook the Tian Shan region. Landslides followed. Huge chunks of rock blocked a gorge. A natural dam was born. Slowly, the valley filled with rainwater and melting glaciers. The water submerged a forest. Spruce trees, some hundreds of years old, ended up underwater.The lake grew gradually. The twisted shapes of trees above the surface, and below, the forest remains almost intact.Experts say the cold water preserved the branches and needles. It seems impossible, but it‚Äôs real. The earthquake didn‚Äôt just shake the ground, which created a tiny underwater time capsule.The trunks look like skeletons. They rise out of the water like fingers reaching for the sky. Some call them ‚Äúmisplaced toothpicks.‚Äù Walking around the lake, it feels surreal. You expect the trees to crumble, but they don‚Äôt. They stand, frozen. Visitors reportedly go in for a swim, though the water is icy. It‚Äôs eerie. But beautiful. You can‚Äôt help staring. The green-blue water shimmers. Limestone carried by the landslide scatters sunlight, giving the lake a strange glow. It‚Äôs almost magical.Diving or peering underwater, the forest continues. Tree trunks stretch down into the icy depths below. The water is crystal-clear. It seems to trap the forest in time. Tiny fish swim around, unnoticed, while the branches remain stiff and brittle. Tourists often gasp when they see it for the first time. There‚Äôs something almost unreal about it. A century-old forest, untouched in its watery grave beneath the silent surface. It makes you wonder how fragile and enduring nature can be at once.Despite being near a city of over a million, the lake feels isolated. Quiet. Almost untouched by modern noise and development. Trails wind around the edges. Locals sometimes guide visitors, sharing stories of the 1911 quake and its sudden, violent aftermath.
Article Summary: Kaindy Lake in Kazakhstan's Tian Shan Mountains is home to a frozen forest preserved in ice. The lake was created by a 1911 earthquake that shook the region. Experts say the water never warms above six degrees, which keeps the trees surprisingly intact.

Article Title: What really destroyed the Indus Valley? It wasn‚Äôt war, but a slow death by drought
Article Text:
Source: Nature

How the Indus Valley built smart cities by the river



How long have droughts slowly broken the Indus Valley



Stone and mud tell the story of the droughts







The Indus Valley Civilisation probably didn‚Äôt disappear all at once. New research points to a long stretch of repeated droughts that may have slowly weakened one of the world‚Äôs earliest urban societies. Cities such as Mohenjo-Daro and Harappa, once built around reliable rivers, appear to have struggled as water became harder to find. As conditions worsened, people began to move away, settlements declined, and everyday life grew uncertain. It‚Äôs striking to realise how deeply something as ordinary as rainfall could shape the fate of an entire civilisation. Researchers believe the damage unfolded over many decades, with early changes so gradual they may have gone almost unnoticed at first.As cited in ScienceDaily study, titled, 'Scientists finally uncovered why the Indus Valley Civilization collapsed', the Indus Valley, also known as the Harappan civilisation, was highly advanced for its time. Cities weren‚Äôt just heaps of bricks; they had organised streets, complex drainage, and water-management systems. Experts say the society had trade links as far as Mesopotamia. They even developed a script, though we can‚Äôt read it today.But life was never entirely smooth. Even with all that clever engineering, the civilisation still depended heavily on the Indus River. When the river‚Äôs flow changed, the whole system started to wobble. Experts note that climate shifts, particularly rainfall patterns, might have slowly made the area harder to live in.Scientists studying this used computer climate simulations spanning thousands of years. These simulations reportedly show rainfall steadily declining between 5,000 and 3,000 years ago, suggesting a prolonged shift in regional climate patterns that reshaped entire ecosystems. Some droughts apparently lasted more than 85 years at a stretch. That‚Äôs a long time without reliable water.It seems that as the droughts dragged on, people moved closer to remaining water sources, abandoning farmlands and trade routes that once sustained thriving urban centres. Eventually, though, even those areas couldn‚Äôt sustain large populations. Cities began to empty. A particularly long drought around 3,500 years ago reportedly coincides with widespread abandonment of major sites. Archaeologists see this as the moment the civilisation really started to unravel.To check the models, researchers looked at stalagmites and stalactites in regional caves. When growth slows, it usually means less rainfall. They also checked lake sediments. Both seem to match the simulations pretty well. It‚Äôs like the environment was leaving a diary, in stone and mud, of exactly what was happening.Nick Scroxton, a climate scientist, reportedly said this work helps explain how changing rainfall influenced urban settlement and agriculture. Liviu Giosan, a geoscientist, called the study ‚Äúa significant step‚Äù in understanding hydroclimate in ancient civilisations. Seems like the scientists were pleased with their cross-checking.
Article Summary: The Indus Valley, also known as the Harappan civilisation, was highly advanced for its time. Cities such as Mohenjo-Daro and Harappa, once built around reliable rivers, appear to have struggled as water became harder to find. Some droughts apparently lasted more than 85 years at a stretch.

Article Title: The Dragon Hole of the South China Sea, where the ocean slowly runs out of oxygen
Article Text:

The Dragon Hole of South China sea remains one of the ocean‚Äôs most unusual blue holes

The Dragon Hole of South China sea remains one of the ocean‚Äôs most unusual blue holes (Image Source - Nature/Scientific Reports/Three-dimensional (3D) morphology of Sansha Yongle Blue Hole in the South China Sea revealed by underwater remotely operated vehicle)

Mapping took longer than expected

Stone walls hint at older shorelines

Oxygen fades quickly below the surface layers





Blue holes are among the least understood features of the ocean floor. From the surface, they can appear ordinary, even calm, blending into the surrounding reef or open water. Below, however, they drop steeply and change quickly. The Sansha Yongle Blue Hole, also known as the Dragon Hole, sits in the South China Sea and has drawn scientific attention for more than a decade. Once confirmed as the deepest known blue hole at just over 301 metres, it has since lost that record to a deeper site in Mexico. Even so, its structure, chemistry and isolation continue to make it one of the most closely studied blue holes in the world. Researchers see it less as a record holder and more as a natural archive shaped by time, water and climate.One of the most striking findings is that the Dragon Hole is not a simple vertical shaft. Detailed surveys show that it bends and tilts as it goes down. The deepest point lies more than 100 metres sideways from the surface entrance. Near the top, the opening is wide. Deeper down, the space narrows sharply, then opens again in places. The uneven form reflects a long and complex history rather than a single collapse.Early attempts to measure the hole were limited by its shape.Turning walls and steep angles confused positioning systems. In 2017, scientists used a high grade underwater robot equipped with precise navigation tools. This made it possible to map the interior in three dimensions and confirm the depth accurately. Multiple instruments were used and cross checked, resulting in a final depth of 301.19 metres with very small uncertainty.For years, the interior resisted clean measurement. Instruments lost their bearings as walls tilted and passages curved. In 2017, researchers returned with a more capable underwater robot, fitted with precise navigation tools. Progress was slow but steady. The result was the first full three dimensional map of the hole, along with a confirmed depth of 301.19 metres. Several instruments were used, checked against one another, then checked again.Inside the hole, the rock tells its own story. Ledges appear at certain depths. Some resemble steps. These features line up with ancient sea levels, formed when the ocean stood lower during colder periods. Fossilised shells and tiny coral fragments are embedded in the walls, hinting at life that once thrived here. The hole seems to have grown in stages, opening and reshaping as water levels rose and fell. Reef limestone dominates the walls, marked by side cavities that appear without warning. Sunlight filters in occasionally, highlighting textures and revealing the subtle colours of ancient deposits.One of the sharpest changes is not in shape, but in chemistry. Below roughly 90 to 100 metres, oxygen nearly disappears. Above this level, some life persists. Below it, conditions turn still and harsh. The water does not mix easily with the surrounding sea. Oxygen is used up and not replaced. In deeper layers, hydrogen sulphide becomes detectable, adding another barrier to life.This lack of circulation gives the Dragon Hole an unusual quality. Water layers remain largely undisturbed, holding chemical signals that reflect past ocean conditions. For scientists, this isolation is valuable. It offers a way to read changes that unfolded slowly, without constant mixing or disruption.
Article Summary: The Sansha Yongle Blue Hole, also known as the Dragon Hole, sits in the South China Sea and has drawn scientific attention for more than a decade. Once confirmed as the deepest known blue hole at just over 301 metres, it has since lost that record to a deeper site in Mexico.
